explanation:
To decide if any operation in OS_CloseAllFiles is dead (i.e. removable without changing program behaviour) you must know which calls and side-effects are required. Reasoning for each symbol:

- OS_ObjectIdIterateActive: Initializes the iterator used by OS_CloseAllFiles. If this function has observable side-effects (registration, global state changes) or is a no-op, it determines whether the initial call is needed.

- OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit: Called by OS_ObjectIdIterateActive according to the static graph; its behaviour (especially side-effects on the iterator or global state) is needed to assess whether the iterate call is required.

- OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext: Controls the loop entry condition. Whether it returns true even once (and any side-effects it performs when advancing) decides if the while-loop body can execute — crucial to determining if the loop and its body are dead.

- OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry: Performs the per-iterator operation and returns close_code. Its implementation determines whether calling it has observable effects (invoking callbacks, modifying globals, producing error codes). If it has no observable effect, calls to it might be dead.

- OS_FileIteratorClose: The callback passed into OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry. Its behaviour (closing file descriptors, updating global state, emitting events) is central to the purpose of OS_CloseAllFiles; if this callback is a no-op the body may be dead.

- OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy: Cleanup after iteration. If this performs required cleanup (releasing resources, committing/canceling transactions) its call is necessary; if it's a no-op it might be removable.

- OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: Called (per static graph) by OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy; its semantics determine whether destruction has observable effects that must be preserved.

- OS_ObjectIdFromToken: Called (per static graph) by OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry; converting tokens to object IDs may have side-effects or be required for correct operation of the callback — needed to judge necessity.

- OS_Lock_Global and OS_Unlock_Global: ProcessEntry (and possibly other iterator functions) lock/unlock global state. These synchronization operations have timing/behavioural impact (note 1 of MISRA guidance) and thus are critical to determine if surrounding calls are removable.

- OS_SUCCESS: The symbolic return value used to initialize return_code and compare close_code against. Its value/meaning is required to know whether assignments/returns in OS_CloseAllFiles are semantically used or redundant.

Together these symbols provide the implementations and side-effect information needed to judge whether the calls and assignments in OS_CloseAllFiles have observable effects (and therefore are not dead) or can be removed without changing program behaviour.
